hook.text: Every loan is a promise to return money you haven't earned yet. You're borrowing from future you.

buildup.text: Debt has existed since before money. Ancient Sumerians recorded debts on clay tablets 5,000 years ago.

discovery.text: At its core, debt is a trust relationship. The lender trusts the borrower to repay.

twist.text: When trust breaks â€” through default or fraud â€” entire financial systems can collapse.

climax.text: The global financial system runs on debt. Government bonds, mortgages, and corporate loans fuel everything.

punchline.text: Debt is a promise about the future.

quiz.question: What is debt at its most fundamental level?
options: A promise to repay borrowed resources

hook.text: A mortgage builds equity. A vacation on a credit card just builds regret. Not all debt is equal.

buildup.text: Good debt finances assets that grow in value or increase your earning power.

discovery.text: Student loans, business loans, and mortgages can be 'good' if they generate returns above their cost.

twist.text: But even 'good' debt can turn bad. A mortgage on a house that loses value is just expensive.

climax.text: The distinction isn't the debt itself â€” it's whether the borrowed money creates more value than it costs.

punchline.text: Good debt makes you richer. Bad debt doesn't.

quiz.question: What makes debt 'good'?
options: It finances something that grows in value
It has a low interest rate

hook.text: You have $50,000. You could buy one house. Or borrow and buy five. That's leverage.

buildup.text: Leverage means using borrowed money to amplify potential returns on an investment.

discovery.text: If your properties rise 10%, you made $25,000 on $50,000 invested â€” a 50% return.

twist.text: If they fall 10%, you lost $25,000. Leverage amplifies losses just as much as gains.

climax.text: The 2008 crisis happened because banks leveraged 30-to-1. A small loss wiped out everything.

punchline.text: Leverage is a magnifying glass for risk.

quiz.question: What is financial leverage?
options: Using borrowed money to amplify returns

hook.text: Ancient Babylon had a rule: every 49 years, all debts were forgiven. A total reset.

buildup.text: Debt jubilees prevented inequality from spiraling out of control in ancient societies.

discovery.text: When debts grew too large, farmers lost their land and became slaves. Jubilees reversed this.

twist.text: Modern student loan forgiveness debates echo the same ancient tension between creditors and debtors.

climax.text: The idea that debts can be too large to repay â€” and should sometimes be forgiven â€” is 4,000 years old.

punchline.text: Debt forgiveness is ancient wisdom.

quiz.question: What was a debt jubilee?
options: A periodic cancellation of all debts
A celebration of paying off debt

hook.text: The US national debt is over $34 trillion. Why does the richest country on Earth borrow at all?

buildup.text: Governments borrow to fund projects that pay off over decades â€” infrastructure, education, defense.

discovery.text: Spreading costs across time means future taxpayers share the burden of things they'll also benefit from.

twist.text: Government debt isn't like household debt. Nations can tax, print money, and roll over bonds indefinitely.

climax.text: The real question isn't the debt size, but whether the borrowed money was spent on productive things.

punchline.text: Nations borrow. The question is what for.

quiz.question: Why do wealthy governments still borrow money?
options: To spread large costs across future generations who benefit
Because they have no tax revenue

hook.text: Miss a car payment and they take the car. Miss a credit card payment and they send angry letters.

buildup.text: Secured debt is backed by collateral â€” an asset the lender can seize if you don't pay.

discovery.text: Mortgages and auto loans are secured. Credit cards and personal loans are unsecured.

twist.text: Secured debt usually has lower interest rates because the lender's risk is lower.

climax.text: Unsecured debt charges more because the lender has no fallback if you default.

punchline.text: Collateral lowers the price of borrowing.

quiz.question: What makes debt 'secured'?
options: It's backed by an asset the lender can seize
It has a fixed interest rate

hook.text: The word 'mortgage' comes from French for 'death pledge.' The debt lasts until it dies â€” or you do.

buildup.text: A mortgage is a loan to buy property, typically repaid over 15 to 30 years.

discovery.text: In the early years, most of your payment goes to interest. The principal barely moves.

twist.text: A 30-year mortgage at 7% means you pay more in interest than the original house price.

climax.text: Despite the cost, mortgages let ordinary people build wealth through property they couldn't buy outright.

punchline.text: The 'death pledge' built the middle class.

quiz.question: What does the word 'mortgage' literally mean?

hook.text: US student loan debt hit $1.7 trillion in 2023. It's now larger than all credit card debt combined.

buildup.text: Student loans fund education under the theory that higher earnings will cover the cost.

discovery.text: A college degree does increase lifetime earnings on average by about $1 million.

twist.text: But averages hide enormous variation. English majors and engineering majors have very different ROIs.

climax.text: Student debt uniquely can't be discharged in bankruptcy. The debt follows you for life.

punchline.text: Education debt is the only kind you can't escape.

quiz.question: What makes US student loans unique among debts?
options: They generally can't be discharged in bankruptcy

hook.text: The average US household with credit card debt owes about $8,000. At 20% interest, that's brutal.

buildup.text: Credit cards offer convenience and rewards, but carrying a balance triggers high interest charges.

discovery.text: Minimum payments are engineered to keep you in debt. They cover interest with tiny principal bites.

twist.text: A $5,000 balance at 20% with minimum payments takes over 20 years and $8,000 in interest to clear.

climax.text: Credit card companies make most profit from people who carry balances, not from annual fees.

punchline.text: Minimum payments are the lender's best friend.

quiz.question: Why are minimum payments on credit cards so low?
options: To maximize the interest the lender collects

hook.text: Two-thirds of US bankruptcies are linked to medical bills. Getting sick can be financially fatal.

buildup.text: The US is the only wealthy nation where medical debt is a leading cause of financial ruin.

discovery.text: Unlike other debts, medical debt is involuntary. Nobody chooses to have a heart attack.

twist.text: Hospital prices vary wildly. The same procedure can cost $3,000 or $30,000 depending on the hospital.

climax.text: Medical debt affects credit scores, job prospects, and housing applications â€” a cascade of consequences.

punchline.text: In America, illness is a financial event.

quiz.question: What fraction of US bankruptcies are linked to medical bills?

hook.text: Borrow $1,000 at 10% simple interest for 10 years: you owe $2,000. Compound: you owe $2,594.

buildup.text: Simple interest charges only on the original amount. Compound interest charges on the growing total.

discovery.text: Most loans use compound interest. The interest itself generates more interest every period.

twist.text: Savings accounts compound in your favor. Debts compound against you. Same math, opposite outcomes.

climax.text: Understanding which type applies to your loans can save or cost thousands over their lifetime.

punchline.text: Compound interest: hero or villain.

quiz.question: What is the key difference between simple and compound interest?
options: Compound charges interest on accumulated interest too

hook.text: Your credit card says 20% APR. Your savings account says 5% APY. They measure different things.

buildup.text: APR is the annual percentage rate â€” the base rate without compounding factored in.

discovery.text: APY includes compounding effects, making it higher than APR for the same nominal rate.

twist.text: Lenders advertise APR on loans to make rates look lower. Banks advertise APY on savings to look higher.

climax.text: Both are legal and accurate. But comparing APR on debt to APY on savings is like apples to oranges.

punchline.text: Read the fine print: APR or APY?

quiz.question: Why do lenders advertise APR instead of APY on loans?
options: APR looks lower because it excludes compounding

hook.text: Charging interest was once considered a sin. All three Abrahamic religions banned it.

buildup.text: Usury â€” charging excessive interest â€” was prohibited in medieval Europe and the Islamic world.

discovery.text: Lenders found creative workarounds: fees, penalties, and profit-sharing that technically weren't interest.

twist.text: Islamic finance today still avoids interest, using profit-sharing and leasing structures instead.

climax.text: The ethical debate about interest hasn't disappeared. Payday lending revives the usury argument today.

punchline.text: The debate over fair interest is ancient.

quiz.question: What is usury?
options: Charging excessively high interest on loans

hook.text: In 2014, the European Central Bank charged banks to hold money. You lost money by saving.

buildup.text: Negative rates mean the lender pays the borrower. It sounds impossible, but it happened.

discovery.text: Central banks use negative rates to force banks to lend money instead of hoarding it.

twist.text: Japan, Switzerland, and the Eurozone all tried it. The results were mixed at best.

climax.text: Negative rates show how far central banks will go to stimulate a stagnant economy.

punchline.text: Sometimes you get paid to borrow.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of negative interest rates?
options: To encourage banks to lend instead of hoarding cash

hook.text: The Fed meets eight times a year to decide one number. Markets hang on every word.

buildup.text: Central banks set a benchmark rate that influences every other interest rate in the economy.

discovery.text: Banks borrow at the benchmark rate and lend at higher rates. The difference is their profit.

twist.text: Your mortgage, car loan, and credit card rates all ripple from that single decision.

climax.text: A 0.25% change seems tiny but moves trillions of dollars across the global financial system.

punchline.text: One number moves the whole economy.

quiz.question: How does the central bank's benchmark rate affect you?
options: It influences all other lending and borrowing rates
It directly sets your mortgage rate

hook.text: In the 1980s, Latin American countries owed more than they could ever repay. They nearly defaulted.

buildup.text: In the 1970s, oil-rich nations deposited petrodollars in Western banks, which lent them to Latin America.

discovery.text: When US interest rates spiked in 1981, these dollar-denominated debts became impossible to service.

twist.text: Mexico announced it couldn't pay in August 1982. A domino effect threatened the entire banking system.

climax.text: The crisis led to a 'lost decade' of economic stagnation across Latin America.

punchline.text: Borrowing in someone else's currency is risky.

quiz.question: What triggered the Latin American debt crisis?
options: US interest rate hikes made dollar debts unaffordable

hook.text: In 1997, Thailand ran out of dollars. Within months, the crisis had spread across all of Asia.

buildup.text: Asian 'tiger' economies had borrowed heavily in dollars while earning in local currencies.

discovery.text: When Thailand's currency collapsed, investors panicked and pulled money from the entire region.

twist.text: The IMF offered bailout loans with strict austerity conditions. Critics called it economic colonialism.

climax.text: Asian nations learned a painful lesson: foreign debt plus currency mismatch equals extreme fragility.

punchline.text: Contagion turns one country's crisis into a continent's.

quiz.question: What made Asian economies vulnerable in 1997?
options: Heavy dollar-denominated debt with local currency earnings

hook.text: Greece joined the euro and borrowed at German interest rates. Then the bill came due.

buildup.text: After joining the eurozone, Greece borrowed cheaply because markets assumed the EU would guarantee debts.

discovery.text: In 2009, Greece revealed its deficit was far larger than reported. Trust evaporated overnight.

twist.text: Greece couldn't devalue its currency â€” it shared the euro. The only option was brutal austerity.

climax.text: GDP fell 25%. Youth unemployment hit 60%. The crisis reshaped European politics for a decade.

punchline.text: Shared currency, unshared consequences.

quiz.question: Why couldn't Greece easily resolve its debt crisis?
options: It shared a currency and couldn't devalue

hook.text: Banks gave mortgages to people who couldn't repay. Then they sold the risk and pretended it was gone.

buildup.text: Subprime loans targeted borrowers with poor credit, offering low 'teaser' rates that later spiked.

discovery.text: Banks bundled these risky loans into securities and sold them as safe investments worldwide.

twist.text: When housing prices fell, defaults cascaded. The 'safe' securities turned out to be worthless.

climax.text: Lehman Brothers collapsed. The global economy nearly followed. Taxpayers funded the bailouts.

punchline.text: Bad loans crashed the global economy.

quiz.question: What were subprime mortgages?
options: Loans given to borrowers with poor credit at high risk

hook.text: When a small bank fails, depositors lose. When a giant bank fails, the whole economy collapses.

buildup.text: 'Too big to fail' means some institutions are so large that their collapse would be catastrophic.

discovery.text: In 2008, the US government bailed out banks with $700 billion in taxpayer money to prevent collapse.

twist.text: This creates moral hazard. If banks know they'll be rescued, they take bigger risks.

climax.text: The Dodd-Frank Act tried to end 'too big to fail.' Critics say the largest banks are even larger now.

punchline.text: Rescue the reckless, and they stay reckless.

quiz.question: What is 'moral hazard' in banking?
options: Banks take more risks knowing they'll be bailed out
Banks become more cautious after crises

hook.text: A two-week payday loan with a $15 fee on $100 sounds small. That's 391% APR.

buildup.text: Payday lenders offer fast cash against your next paycheck, targeting people with no other options.

discovery.text: 80% of payday loans are rolled over or followed by another loan within 14 days.

twist.text: The average borrower spends 200 days per year in payday loan debt. It's designed to be permanent.

climax.text: Payday lenders cluster in low-income neighborhoods. There are more payday shops than McDonald's in the US.

punchline.text: Short-term loans become long-term traps.

quiz.question: What is the effective APR of a typical payday loan?

hook.text: Your $3,000 credit card balance has a $60 minimum payment. You'll be paying for 15 years.

buildup.text: Minimum payments are usually 1-3% of the balance â€” barely covering interest.

discovery.text: On a $3,000 balance at 18%, minimum payments cost over $4,000 in interest alone.

twist.text: Banks set minimums low deliberately. The longer you pay, the more interest they earn.

climax.text: Paying even $20 above the minimum can cut repayment time in half. Small increases matter enormously.

punchline.text: The minimum keeps you in debt by design.

quiz.question: Why do banks set minimum payments so low?
options: To maximize the interest they collect over time

hook.text: People in debt are three times more likely to suffer from depression. The link is well documented.

buildup.text: Debt creates chronic stress. The constant worry about payments activates the brain's threat response.

discovery.text: Financial stress impairs sleep, relationships, and job performance â€” making the debt even harder to repay.

twist.text: Shame keeps people silent. Many hide their debt from partners and friends, increasing isolation.

climax.text: Addressing debt as a health issue, not just a financial one, leads to better outcomes.

punchline.text: Debt doesn't just cost money. It costs health.

quiz.question: How much more likely are people in debt to experience depression?

hook.text: Miss one payment. Late fee added. Balance grows. Next month's minimum is higher. You miss again.

buildup.text: Debt snowballs when penalties and interest cause the balance to grow faster than payments can reduce it.

discovery.text: Penalty interest rates on credit cards can jump to 29% or higher after a single missed payment.

twist.text: One financial shock â€” a car repair, medical bill â€” can trigger a cascade that lasts years.

climax.text: Breaking the snowball requires either a lump payment, consolidation, or negotiation with creditors.

punchline.text: Debt grows fastest when you can least afford it.

quiz.question: What triggers the debt snowball effect?
options: Penalties and interest growing faster than payments

hook.text: Bankruptcy sounds like financial death. In reality, it's a legal reset button.

buildup.text: US bankruptcy law exists to give people a fresh start when debts become truly unpayable.

discovery.text: Chapter 7 wipes out most debts but may require selling assets. Chapter 13 creates a repayment plan.

twist.text: Bankruptcy stays on your credit report for 7-10 years, but recovery starts immediately after filing.

climax.text: Famous people who went bankrupt include Walt Disney, Henry Ford, and Abraham Lincoln.

punchline.text: Bankruptcy is an ending and a beginning.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of bankruptcy law?
options: To give people a fresh start from unpayable debts

topics.title: What a Credit Score Really Is

hook.text: A three-digit number determines your mortgage rate, apartment, and sometimes even your job.

buildup.text: Credit scores rank your likelihood of repaying debt, from 300 (risky) to 850 (near-perfect).

discovery.text: Payment history counts most â€” about 35%. Then amounts owed, length of history, and types of credit.

twist.text: Having no debt doesn't mean a good score. You need active credit accounts to build a history.

climax.text: The system rewards borrowing and repaying, not avoiding debt entirely. It's designed for borrowers.

punchline.text: Your financial life distilled to three digits.

quiz.question: What factor matters most in a credit score?

hook.text: Before 1989, getting a loan meant a banker judged you by handshake, appearance, and neighborhood.

buildup.text: Fair Isaac Corporation created the FICO score to standardize lending decisions objectively.

discovery.text: Automated scoring removed some human bias. Loan decisions became faster and more consistent.

twist.text: But the data reflects existing inequalities. Historical discrimination echoes through credit algorithms.

climax.text: Credit scores democratized borrowing but also created a new system where past mistakes linger for years.

punchline.text: Algorithms replaced handshakes.

quiz.question: Why were credit scores invented?
options: To standardize and speed up lending decisions

hook.text: Using 90% of your credit limit tanks your score even if you pay on time. The ratio matters.

buildup.text: Credit utilization is how much of your available credit you're currently using.

discovery.text: Experts recommend keeping utilization below 30%. Under 10% is even better for your score.

twist.text: Paradoxically, having a higher credit limit improves your score â€” even if you don't use it.

climax.text: The scoring system rewards having access to credit while barely using it. Restraint is the signal.

punchline.text: Having credit matters more than using it.

quiz.question: What credit utilization ratio is recommended?

hook.text: One in five credit reports contains an error. Yours might be costing you money right now.

buildup.text: Credit bureaus â€” Equifax, Experian, TransUnion â€” collect data from lenders and build your file.

discovery.text: Mistakes happen: wrong balances, accounts that aren't yours, outdated information.

twist.text: You're entitled to a free credit report yearly, but most people never check it.

climax.text: Disputing errors is free and can significantly improve your score overnight.

punchline.text: Check your report. Errors are common.

quiz.question: How common are errors in credit reports?
options: About one in five reports has an error

hook.text: Millions of Americans are 'credit invisible' â€” no credit history at all. It locks many doors.

buildup.text: About 26 million US adults have no credit file. Another 19 million have files too thin to score.

discovery.text: Without a score, renting an apartment, getting a phone plan, or buying a car becomes far harder.

twist.text: Immigrants, young adults, and low-income communities are disproportionately credit invisible.

climax.text: New models using rent and utility payments aim to score people without traditional credit histories.

punchline.text: No credit history is almost worse than bad credit.

quiz.question: How many US adults are 'credit invisible'?
